abstract: Creating a document in Microsoft Word and need to put in sample text to hold the space until the real copy arrives?
snippet: Creating a document in Microsoft Word and need to put in sample text to hold the space until the real copy arrives?
lead_paragraph: Creating a document in Microsoft Word and need to put in sample text to hold the space until the real copy arrives? You don’t have to cut and paste a thing  and you can tell Word exactly how much fake text to supply. Say you want to add four paragraphs of three sentences each. In your document, just type in “=rand(4,3)” on its own line, without the quotation marks, and press the Enter key. Word fills the space with text in the requested amount of paragraphs and sentences. The content varies with the version of Word. More details and instructions are at www.support.microsoft.com/kb/212251.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Faking Text in Word

abstract: Australia’s economic expansion slowed to the weakest rate in more than three years as consumers reduced spending, stoking speculation the central bank would cut interest rates again.
snippet: Australia’s economic expansion slowed to the weakest rate in more than three years as consumers reduced spending, stoking speculation the central bank would cut interest rates again.
lead_paragraph: Australia’s economic expansion slowed to the weakest rate in more than three years as consumers reduced spending, stoking speculation the central bank would cut interest rates again. Gross domestic product rose 0.3 percent from the first quarter, when it increased a revised 0.7 percent, the Bureau of Statistics said. The economy grew 2.7 percent from a year earlier. Australia’s dollar fell to its lowest level in a year, and stocks slid. The report supported comments by Glenn Stevens, the central bank governor, who said that he had more scope to cut rates as consumer spending, business confidence and stock-market values slump. The bank reduced the overnight cash rate target on Tuesday by a quarter percentage point to 7 percent, from a 12-year high of 6.75 percent.

headline.main: Australia: Economic Expansion Slows
headline.print_headline: AUSTRALIA: ECONOMIC EXPANSION SLOWS

abstract: Total, the French oil company, agreed to buy Talisman Energy’s assets in the Dutch sector of the North Sea for $480 million.
snippet: Total, the French oil company, agreed to buy Talisman Energy’s assets in the Dutch sector of the North Sea for $480 million.
lead_paragraph: Total, the French oil company, agreed to buy Talisman Energy’s assets in the Dutch sector of the North Sea for $480 million. The purchase includes three field stakes with production in 2007 equivalent to about 23 million cubic feet of natural gas a day, Talisman said. The purchase will increase Total’s reserves and production in the Netherlands in 2011 by about 20 percent, or by about 8,000 barrels of oil a day, Total said. Total is based in Paris and Talisman is based in Calgary, Alberta.

headline.main: France: Total to Buy Energy Assets

abstract: Remember early this year, after Howard Schultz reclaimed his troubled, beloved Starbucks, and promised to make radical changes? How he said he would recapture the old Starbucks experience? How he vowed to make Starbucks a warmer, friendlier place with a more consistent cup of coffee? And most importantly (from my point at least), how he vowed to get rid of those warm breakfast sandwiches that were a) inedible and b) smelling up the joint? I hear through the grapevine that he would tell people flatly: “The egg sandwiches are gone.”
lead_paragraph: Remember early this year, after Howard Schultz reclaimed his troubled, beloved Starbucks, and promised to make radical changes? I hear through the grapevine that he would tell people flatly: “The egg sandwiches are gone.”

lead_paragraph: AS banks tighten lending standards, alternative sources like Virgin Money USA are stepping into the breach. Last year, Richard Branson, chairman of the Virgin Group, acquired a majority stake in the company, formerly called CircleLending. Unlike a traditional bank, which pools its available lending funds from various sources, Virgin Money organizes and processes loans among family, friends and business associates. The company says it has originated $350 million in loans since 2001 and has grown 75 percent in the last 11 months.

abstract: Back in 2001, when Bill Miller was viewed as one of the world’s greatest investors, I edited a story about him at Fortune magazine. Mr. Miller, of course, is the manager of the Legg Mason Value Trust mutual fund, whose claim to fame is that he beat the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index for 15 years straight. (It was 10 straight when Fortune published its story.) In the last few years, however, his fund has stumbled badly. Indeed, there are those in the investment community who whisper that Mr. Miller was never really a truly great investor. Rather, he was akin to the guy who flips a coin and it comes up heads 15 straight times — a product, that is, of randomness rather than skill.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2001, when Bill Miller was viewed as one of the world’s greatest investors, I edited a story about him at Fortune magazine. Indeed, there are those in the investment community who whisper that Mr. Miller was never really a truly great investor. Rather, he was akin to the guy who flips a coin and it comes up heads 15 straight times — a product, that is, of randomness rather than skill.

abstract: An article on Monday about the potential winners and losers among investors after the federal rescue of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac erroneously included one major Wall Street investor on a list of value-oriented money managers who invested in the mortgage companies. The investor, Martin Whitman, of Third Avenue Management, has made large investments in other distressed financials, including MBIA and Ambac, but his fund does not own shares of Freddie or Fannie. The article also misstated the date that the contract of Richard F. Syron, the chief executive of Freddie Mac, was extended and amended to increase his potential severance package. It was November 2007, not July 2008.
snippet: An article on Monday about the potential winners and losers among investors after the federal rescue of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac erroneously included one major Wall Street investor on a list of value-oriented money managers who invested in the m...
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about the potential winners and losers among investors after the federal rescue of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac erroneously included one major Wall Street investor on a list of value-oriented money managers who invested in the mortgage companies. The investor, Martin Whitman, of Third Avenue Management, has made large investments in other distressed financials, including MBIA and Ambac, but his fund does not own shares of Freddie or Fannie. The article also misstated the date that the contract of Richard F. Syron, the chief executive of Freddie Mac, was extended and amended to increase his potential severance package. It was November 2007, not July 2008.

headline.main: Corrections
headline.print_headline: Corrections

lead_paragraph: You would be forgiven for thinking that after I.B.M. sold off its storied disk drive business to Hitachi in 2002 for $2 billion, Big Blue was out of the storage business. Not so, I.B.M. said at the time, we’re just getting out of the low-margin hardware side of storage, disk drives. But most people, understandably, watched the deal and the heritage — I.B.M. was a pioneering innovator in disk drive technology — being sold off to the Japanese.

headline.main: I.B.M. Returns to the Storage Market

abstract: Bill Rancic, who was the first “Apprentice” winner, has come full circle — from reality show contestant to host — with a new reality television series, “We Mean Business.”
snippet: Bill Rancic, who was the first “Apprentice” winner, has come full circle — from reality show contestant to host — with a new reality television series, “We Mean Business.”
lead_paragraph: Since he was chosen by Donald Trump to be the first “Apprentice” on the television show in 2004, Bill Rancic has been busy with entrepreneurial projects, many of which have to do with the business of reality television. As the winner of that show, he was awarded a job with the Trump organization. In addition to his relationship to Trump projects — he occasionally fills in as a judge on “The Apprentice” — Mr. Rancic works as a real estate developer, has had his own television show on iVillage, speaks on entrepreneurship, published two books and appears to have time to still run a bevy of other business ventures. His personal life has kept him in the news as well. Last year, he married the E! anchor, Giuliana DePandi (who now goes by Giuliana Rancic). The two started a television production company, You and I Productions, together.

headline.main: New Reality Show “Fixes” Small Businesses

abstract: Mexico’s inflation accelerated to the fastest annual pace in more than five years last month on higher costs for gasoline, electricity and eggs.
snippet: Mexico’s inflation accelerated to the fastest annual pace in more than five years last month on higher costs for gasoline, electricity and eggs.
lead_paragraph: Mexico’s inflation accelerated to the fastest annual pace in more than five years last month on higher costs for gasoline, electricity and eggs. Consumer prices increased 5.57 percent from a year earlier, the most since December 2002. Prices climbed 0.58 percent from July, the central bank said. Inflation was in line with forecasts, and not fast enough to persuade the central bank to raise the benchmark interest rate this month, said Rodrigo Valdes, chief Latin American economist at Barclays Capital. The price increases also met the expectation of central bank policy makers, who have forecast year-on-year inflation of 5.25 percent to 5.75 percent in the third quarter.

headline.main: Mexico: Inflation at 5-year High
headline.print_headline: MEXICO: INFLATION AT 5-YEAR HIGH

abstract: A rash of small business contests has turned small business owners into get-out-the-vote advocates — for their own companies.
snippet: A rash of small business contests has turned small business owners into get-out-the-vote advocates — for their own companies.
lead_paragraph: Lately it’s not just the presidential candidates who are seeking votes. With the increasing popularity of small business contests, entrepreneurs are also orchestrating their own get-out-the-vote efforts. Contests exist in just about every niche. StartupNation is currently running its second annual contest for home-based businesses, sponsored by Microsoft Office Live Small Business. American Express sponsors the Make Mine a Million and Micro to Millions contests through Count Me In, which awards loans as well as business coaching and other support to qualifying female-owned businesses. Others, like Ideablob, from the credit card issuer Advanta are more general — $10,000 monthly prizes are awarded to anyone with a winning business idea.

headline.main: Entrepreneurs Get Out the Vote, for Themselves

abstract: Most browsers these days -- including the current versions of Internet Explorer, Firefox and Safari -- let you zoom in on the page with a quick keyboard shortcut.
snippet: Most browsers these days -- including the current versions of Internet Explorer, Firefox and Safari -- let you zoom in on the page with a quick keyboard shortcut.
lead_paragraph: Tired of squinting to see the smaller elements of a Web page like comments and picture captions? Most browsers these days  including the current versions of Internet Explorer, Firefox and Safari  let you zoom in on the page with a quick keyboard shortcut. On a Windows-run machine, press the Control and + (plus) keys to enlarge the page, and Control and  (minus) to decrease the size of the page view. On a Mac, press the Command key along with the + and  keys to zoom in and out. Press Control (or Command) and the 0 (zero) key to return the page to 100 percent.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Shortcuts for Zooming

abstract: Employers hired almost three times as many workers in August as economists had forecast, adding to evidence that an Australian mining boom is offsetting weaker domestic demand.
snippet: Employers hired almost three times as many workers in August as economists had forecast, adding to evidence that an Australian mining boom is offsetting weaker domestic demand.
lead_paragraph: Employers hired almost three times as many workers in August as economists had forecast, adding to evidence that an Australian mining boom is offsetting weaker domestic demand. The number of people employed rose 14,600 last month, the Australian Statistics Bureau said. Economists had forecast an increase of 5,000. The jobless rate fell to 4.1 percent, from 4.3 percent. The number of full-time jobs rose about 7,500 in August and part-time jobs increased roughly 7,200. The August employment gain followed a revised increase of 18,700 jobs in July. Demand for skilled labor at companies including BHP Billiton is helping generate new jobs.

headline.main: Australia: Job Creation Tops Forecasts
headline.print_headline: AUSTRALIA: JOB CREATION TOPS FORECASTS

abstract: The country lost more than twice as many jobs in the second quarter as initially reported as economic growth contracted for the first time in more than five years.
snippet: The country lost more than twice as many jobs in the second quarter as initially reported as economic growth contracted for the first time in more than five years.
lead_paragraph: The country lost more than twice as many jobs in the second quarter as initially reported as economic growth contracted for the first time in more than five years. Payrolls in France, excluding government employees, farm workers and the self-employed, declined by 28,800, or 0.2 percent, to 16.04 million from the first quarter, the statistics office Insee said. It was the first payroll decrease in more than four years. On Aug. 14, Insee released an initial estimate of 12,200 jobs lost in the quarter. “The economic slowdown has hit employment faster than usual,” said Dominique Barbet, an economist at BNP Paribas in Paris. “Employment declines will weigh on income and confidence and prevent a significant economic recovery.”

headline.main: France: Job Loss Figure Raised
headline.print_headline: FRANCE: JOB LOSS FIGURE RAISED

abstract: Machinery orders in Japan fell in July for a second consecutive month, an indication that manufacturers expect the global slowdown to crimp demand into next year.
snippet: Machinery orders in Japan fell in July for a second consecutive month, an indication that manufacturers expect the global slowdown to crimp demand into next year.
lead_paragraph: Machinery orders in Japan fell in July for a second consecutive month, an indication that manufacturers expect the global slowdown to crimp demand into next year. Orders, an indicator of capital spending in the next three to six months, declined 3.9 percent from June, when they slid 2.6 percent, the cabinet office said. From a year earlier, orders fell 4.7 percent, the first decline in four months, the office said. The value of orders placed from abroad, a figure excluded from the orders number, declined to the lowest level in two years. That “suggests that the slowdown in the global economy is starting to have a material impact on the machinery sector,” said Hiroshi Shiraishi, an economist at Lehman Brothers Holdings in Tokyo.

headline.main: Japan: Machinery Orders Fall
headline.print_headline: JAPAN: MACHINERY ORDERS FALL

lead_paragraph: It was no ordinary Friday at Lehman Brothers. “You Shook Me All Night Long” by AC/DC blared from speakers inside the bank’s Midtown headquarters. Employees polished résumés. And, by midafternoon, the word came from the 31st floor: the fate of the stricken bank would be decided by Sunday.

abstract: The mutual fund giant will buy back $300 million worth of auction-rate securities by the end of the year as part of a settlement with the New York attorney general’s office.
snippet: The mutual fund giant will buy back $300 million worth of auction-rate securities by the end of the year as part of a settlement with the New York attorney general’s office.
lead_paragraph: Fidelity Investments, the mutual fund giant, will buy back $300 million worth of auction-rate securities by the end of the year as part of a settlement with the New York attorney general’s office. According to the terms of the deal, Fidelity will not pay a fine. Most of the large originators of auction-rate securities have already reached settlements with state regulators and the Securities and Exchange Commission. The banks held the auctions at which interest rates on these securities were reset, often weekly. After the onset of the credit crisis, they began saddling investors with securities they could not resell. So far the big banks have repurchased more than $35 billion of the securities and paid more than $360 million in fines.

headline.main: Fidelity in Securities Settlement With New York

abstract: An article on Sept. 3 about a pledge by officials of the telecommunications company Alcatel-Lucent that they would push ahead with the integration of the troubled French-American company misstated the number of jobs the company had cut since it was created in a 2006 merger. lead_paragraph: Volvo, the auto maker, said August truck deliveries rose 4 percent as Asian demand more than compensated for weaker sales in the United States and Western Europe. The company sold 14,849 trucks under its Volvo, Nissan Diesel, Renault Trucks, Mack and Eicher brands, compared with 14,277 a year earlier, the company said. Group sales in Europe fell 10 percent because of a 17 percent decline in Western Europe. North American sales fell 18 percent with Mack reporting a decline of 19 percent. Volvo is based in Gothenburg, Sweden.

abstract: Barclays’ move to snap up Lehman Brothers’ broker-dealer operations for around $250 million — and take its New York headquarters and some data centers in New Jersey for an additional $1.5 billion or so — would have been unthinkable just a few days ago. But on Wednesday, a bankruptcy judge signed off on the proposed sale process. The terms call for a break-up fee of $100 million, which Lehman must pay to Barclays if it accepts another bid (which seems highly unlikely at this point).

abstract: An article in the special Wealth and Personal Finance section on Sept. 10 about tax planning gave an incorrect attribution for a quotation about the dangers of inherited wealth. It was Scott D. Michel, a tax lawyer at Caplin & Drysdale — not Scott J. Bakal, a tax lawyer at Neal Gerber Eisenberg — who said: “You almost never see a criminal tax case where you have inherited wealth, because they come with inherited lawyers, inherited advisers, inherited accountants. There’s a structure in place. With people who start from nothing and end up under a waterfall of money, the structure isn’t there, and there’s nobody to say ‘no’ to an abusive shelter.

abstract: French consumer spending on manufactured goods fell more than expected in August.
snippet: French consumer spending on manufactured goods fell more than expected in August.
lead_paragraph: French consumer spending on manufactured goods fell more than expected in August. Household spending on such goods, which accounts for about 15 percent of the economy, fell 0.3 percent from July, when it had risen 0.4 percent, Insee, the national statistics office, said. Spending declined 0.1 percent from a year earlier, the first year-on-year drop since September 1997. “Spending has been flat over the past six months,” said Maryse Pogodzinski, an economist at JPMorgan Chase in Paris. “Shoppers have been hit in the face by huge price increases in food and energy, and now the job market is deteriorating.”

headline.main: France: Consumers Cut Spending on Goods
headline.print_headline: FRANCE: CONSUMERS CUT SPENDING ON GOODS

abstract: Consumer prices rose 3.5 percent from a year earlier, the biggest increase since March 2003, Statistics Canada said.
snippet: Consumer prices rose 3.5 percent from a year earlier, the biggest increase since March 2003, Statistics Canada said.
lead_paragraph: Canada’s annual inflation rate rose to the highest in more than five years in August as prices for gasoline and food surged. Consumer prices rose 3.5 percent from a year earlier, the biggest increase since March 2003, Statistics Canada said. Prices fell 0.2 percent from July. Excluding gasoline and seven other volatile items, inflation rose 1.7 percent in August from a year earlier, and 0.3 percent from July. Economists predicted that figure, the so-called core rate, would gain 1.5 percent from a year earlier and 0.1 percent on a monthly basis.

headline.main: Canada: Inflation at Highest Rate in Five Years
headline.print_headline: CANADA: INFLATION AT HIGHEST RATE IN FIVE YEARS

lead_paragraph: Subtle career shifts can be as daunting as dramatic reinventions. And today we have a guest post by Linda Villarosa, focusing on one of those subtle shifts. Ms. Villarosa, a career journalist and nonfiction author, has just published her first novel, “Passing for Black.” I asked her to write about what it feels like to make the move from journalist to novelist. Here is what she had to say. — Marci

headline.main: From Journalist to Novelist

abstract: The final-days priorities of the Bush administration are undergoing a stark reordering due to the current economic turmoil.

headline.main: Economy Overshadows Bush’s Agenda as His Term Winds Down

As a follow-up, I sent an e-mail to Amy Finkelstein — a young M.I.T. economist who has written a paper arguing that electronic toll systems, like E-ZPass, typically lead to toll increases — to see what she thought about candy-bar economics. Shereplies:

abstract: Today’s guest blogger is Daniel Alpert, a managing director at Westwood Capital, whom I’ve quoted quite a bit in my column the last few months. Why? Because he has been dead spot on in anticipating virtually every iteration of this crisis. Last night he sent me (and others) this note about the testimony of Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. and Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke. It aptly sums the current the state of play. I asked him if I could reprint his note here at Executive Suite. Happily, he agreed.

abstract: Strong ratings for the new whodunit crime show â€œThe Mentalistâ€ helped CBS eke out a slight victory on Tuesday as the most watched network despite day two of ABCâ€™s ratings juggernaut â€œDancing With the Stars.â€ According to Nielsenâ€™s estimates, the new 9 p.m. drama, with Australian actor Simon Baker in the lead role, attracted 15.5 million viewers, nearly 5 million better than CBS’s premiere of “The Unit” in the same time period a year ago. “The Mentalist” made its debut in a plum time slot wedged between CBSâ€™s â€œNCISâ€ at 8 p.m., which garnered its largest premiere audience in its six seasons (17.7 million), and â€œWithout a Traceâ€ at 10 p.m. (11.4 million). Among adults 18 to 49, however, CBS ranked third behind second place ABC with its two-hour block of â€œDancing With the Starsâ€ from 9 to 11 p.m. (18.2 million) and Fox, which led the night in that age group despite lagging in third in total viewers. Fox broadcast â€œHouseâ€ at 8 p.m. (12.1 million) and â€œFringeâ€ at 9 p.m. (9.7 million). ABC would have won the night outright had it not trailed badly during the 8 p.m. hour with the debut of its new family game show â€œOpportunity Knocksâ€ (6.6 million). NBC finished fourth, drawing 7.2 million for â€œThe Biggest Loserâ€ from 8 to 10 p.m. followed by â€œLaw & Order: Special Victims Unitâ€ in the 10 p.m. time slot (9.5 million). NBC nearly tied CBS for third place in the 18-to-49 set. Finally, the CW, in fifth place as usual, earned 3 million viewers for “90210” at 8 p.m. but just 1.9 million for “Privileged” at 9 p.m.

lead_paragraph: Strong ratings for the new whodunit crime show “The Mentalist” helped CBS eke out a slight victory on Tuesday as the most-watched network despite Day 2 of ABC’s ratings juggernaut “Dancing With the Stars.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, the new 9 p.m. drama, with the Australian actor Simon Baker in the lead role, attracted 15.5 million viewers, nearly 5 million better than CBS’s premiere of “The Unit” in the same time period a year ago.

Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. Nike sold its Bauer Hockey unit in February for $200 million to an investor group led by Kohlberg & Company and a Canadian businessman, W. Graeme Roustan.

abstract: The Mazda Motor Corporation will be the first Japanese auto company to ship vehicles within Russia via the Trans-Siberian Railroad.
snippet: The Mazda Motor Corporation will be the first Japanese auto company to ship vehicles within Russia via the Trans-Siberian Railroad.
lead_paragraph: The Mazda Motor Corporation will become the first Japanese auto company to ship vehicles within Russia via the Trans-Siberian Railroad. Mazda, which is based in Hiroshima, might begin shipments later this week, said Yekaterina Kulbaka, marketing director for RailTransAuto, which will operate the trains and manage logistics. The carmaker plans to ship 30 percent of its vehicle imports in Russia by railroad to cut transportation expenses, Mr. Kulbaka said. The Trans-Siberian railroad links Vladivostok on the Pacific coast to the European part of Russia.

lead_paragraph: I recently read Bryan Caplan‘s book “The Myth of the Rational Voter: Why Democracies Choose Bad Policies,” which argues that voters are systematically biased against good economic policy. (Good economic policy in this case is generally defined as whatever ideas economists agree upon.) Professor Caplan argues that it is therefore in politicians’ best interest to advocate bad economic policies. Inversely, any politician who pushes sound economic policies — or worse, is a trained economist — will have a tough time getting elected.

headline.main: Could an Economist Ever Be Elected President?

abstract: Politicians who worry about manipulation of balance sheets should turn their attention on themselves.
snippet: Politicians who worry about manipulation of balance sheets should turn their attention on themselves.
lead_paragraph: This is the second in a series on ways in which Washington’s economic policies mimic the same types of financial irresponsibility it chastises Wall Street for. Financial gymnastics: Washington has complained that Wall Street banks made the securities, swaps and other complicated things they exchange incomprehensible in order to make them look more valuable. Politicians complain that banks dragged their feet about writing down the value of troubled assets and should quit grumbling about transparency-promoting accounting standards like mark-to-market provisions. Why can’t Wall Street just be honest about what these things are worth, huh? Why do sneaky banks have to slice and dice the things they own to obfuscate, or outright misrepresent, their value?

The partnership lets AT&T compete with cable companies’ “triple play” plans in markets where AT&T, the nation’s biggest phone company, does not have its own television service. Terms of the multiyear deal were not disclosed.

snippet: The world’s biggest pork processor said it would be in compliance with all its financial covenants through at least April after its shares plunged to a seven-year low in New York trading.
lead_paragraph: Smithfield Foods, the world’s biggest pork processor, said it would be in compliance with all its financial covenants through at least April after its shares plunged to a seven-year low in New York trading. “The company has no significant debt payments due until late into calendar 2009,” Smithfield said in a statement. The company’s shares dropped earlier Friday on concerns it might not meet its debt covenants. Shares on Friday fell 21 percent, to $13.98, before closing at $17.11, a loss of 3 percent. Last month, Smithfield reported its first quarterly loss in 10 years as rising grain prices increased the cost of feeding hogs and turkeys.

lead_paragraph: Autobytel, the operator of MyRide.com and other automobile-shopping sites on the Internet, said that it would cut more than a third of its work force and that it had hired RBC Capital Markets to explore a possible sale of the company. “Our current stock price as well as overall market conditions are conducive to, and have driven, increased interest in Autobytel from various third parties,” the company’s chief executive, Jim Riesenbach, said in a statement. “We stand ready to take whatever action is necessary to maximize shareholder value.” Autobytel, based in Irvine, Calif., closed up nearly 6 percent, at $1.07. The stock had lost 63 percent this year before Friday.

abstract: A.I.G., the insurer that agreed to a government takeover to avert collapse, reached a deal to sell its 50 percent stake in London City Airport to its partners in the venture.
snippet: A.I.G., the insurer that agreed to a government takeover to avert collapse, reached a deal to sell its 50 percent stake in London City Airport to its partners in the venture.
lead_paragraph: The American International Group, the insurer that agreed to a government takeover to avert collapse, reached a deal to sell its 50 percent stake in London City Airport to its partners in the venture. Global Infrastructure Partners, the private equity fund started by the Credit Suisse Group and General Electric, bought out A.I.G.’s stake in the airport, said Rupa Haria, a spokeswoman for London City. The deal will be completed in October. A.I.G. is selling businesses to repay an $85 billion loan. London City was acquired by A.I.G. and Global Infrastructure in 2006

headline.main: Britain: A.I.G. Sells Airport Stake

abstract: Akzo Nobel, the paint maker, postponed a $2.3 billion stock repurchase plan, as the credit market freeze-up hampered its ability to refinance loans.
snippet: Akzo Nobel, the paint maker, postponed a $2.3 billion stock repurchase plan, as the credit market freeze-up hampered its ability to refinance loans.
lead_paragraph: Akzo Nobel, the paint maker, postponed a 1.6 billion-euro ($2.3 billion) stock repurchase plan, as the credit market freeze-up hampered its ability to refinance loans. “There’s no liquidity,” the chief financial officer Keith Nichols said in an interview. “So it may take longer” to refinance “or we’ll have to do a portion ourselves.” The company has 800 million euros of bonds due by the end of this year and an additional 1 billion euros in early May. Akzo Nobel already bought back shares as a pledge to investors to gain their support for the $15.9 billion purchase of Imperial Chemical Industries, the owner of the Dulux and Glidden brands. The company said it would cut 3,500 jobs to speed up the integration of ICI as paint demand weakens.

headline.main: Netherlands: Akzo Delays Buyback
headline.print_headline: NETHERLANDS: AKZO DELAYS BUYBACK

abstract: Cash America International, the world’s largest pawnshop operator, said it would spend $90 million for an 80 percent interest in the owner of 100 similar stores in Mexico.
snippet: Cash America International, the world’s largest pawnshop operator, said it would spend $90 million for an 80 percent interest in the owner of 100 similar stores in Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Cash America International, the world’s largest pawnshop operator, said it would spend $90 million for an 80 percent interest in the owner of 100 similar stores in Mexico. The company will also pay an amount tied to future performance for the stake in the owner of Prenda Fácil pawnshops in 16 Mexican states, Cash America said. Fewer people in Mexico use banks than in the United States, making it an attractive market for pawn-shop owners like Cash America and a competitor, First Cash Financial Services, said Elizabeth Pierce, an analyst for Roth Capital Partners. Prenda Fácil’s receivables were $21.5 million on June 30, Cash America said. The company expects the purchase to add to 2009 earnings.

headline.main: Cash America Buys Pawnshop Stake
headline.print_headline: CASH AMERICAN BUYS PAWNSHOP STAKE

abstract: Hynix Semiconductor’s biggest shareholders agreed to sell their $2.7 billion stake.
snippet: Hynix Semiconductor’s biggest shareholders agreed to sell their $2.7 billion stake.
lead_paragraph: Hynix Semiconductor’s biggest shareholders agreed to sell their 3.2 trillion won ($2.7 billion) stake, allowing creditors to end their ties with the world’s second-largest chip maker seven years after a bailout. All nine creditors have agreed to sell the combined 36 percent stake, according to the Seoul-based Korea Exchange Bank, Hynix’s main creditor. Preparations, including the selection of a sale arranger, will begin after mid-October, an e-mail statement from Korea Exchange said. The move allows creditors to dispose of a company they bailed out in 2001 as a glut threatens to erode earnings for memory chipmakers. The sale also comes in a global credit crisis that has forced banks and brokerages to write down more than $550 billion in credit-related losses.

headline.main: South Korea: Hynix Investors Sell Stake
headline.print_headline: SOUTH KOREA: HYNIX INVESTORS SELL STAKE

abstract: Textron, the maker of Cessna and Bell aircraft, said it is building a plant in Mexico’s Chihuahua state to produce parts for the Bell 429 commercial helicopter.

lead_paragraph: Textron, the maker of Cessna and Bell aircraft, said it is building a plant in Mexico’s Chihuahua state to produce parts for the Bell 429 commercial helicopter. The plant, which will operate as Textron International Mexico, eventually will employ 375 people, Textron said in a statement. The parts will be shipped to Canada for final assembly. Bell contributed about 30 percent of the company’s total revenue of $13.3 billion in 2007.

Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, was the only Wall Street chief executive who attended the Monday meeting, not the only chief executive who attended weekend meetings. Also, Henry M. Paulson Jr., the Treasury secretary, did not lead or attend the Monday meeting. (Both Mr. Blankfein and Mr. Paulson did attend the weekend meetings.).

snippet: Week two of “Dancing With the Stars” remained strong in the ratings on Monday as 19.3 million viewers tuned in to ABC from 8 to 10 p.m.
lead_paragraph: Week two of “Dancing With the Stars” remained strong in the ratings on Monday as 19.3 million viewers tuned in to ABC from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although that tally was down 2 million compared to its premiere a week ago, the reality competition remained far and away the night’s top-rated show.

headline.main: Monday Ratings: ‘Dancing’ Remains Strong

abstract: As banks and politicians press to be allowed to stop using market values in their financial statements, the SEC and the Financial Accounting Standards Board are about to issue some sort of statement.
snippet: As banks and politicians press to be allowed to stop using market values in their financial statements, the SEC and the Financial Accounting Standards Board are about to issue some sort of statement.
lead_paragraph: As the political pressure grows to do something to change fair value accounting — which the banks blame for their problems — we may be nearing a climax before the next House vote on the bailout package.

headline.main: Fair Value Follies

abstract: The United States government is the biggest of the Too-Big-to-Fails. Today’s private sector financial mess provides a great excuse to prevent tomorrow’s public sector one.
snippet: The United States government is the biggest of the Too-Big-to-Fails. Today’s private sector financial mess provides a great excuse to prevent tomorrow’s public sector one.
lead_paragraph: We’ve established a few parallels between Wall Street’s and Washington’s financial profligacy: self-servingly wishful logic, financial gymnastics, poor oversight/risk management mechanisms and lack of leadership accountability.

headline.main: Look in the Mirror, Washington: Part V (Or: What’s the Point of This Series, Exactly?)

abstract: Politicians and theologians argue over how best to curb a perceived culture of escalating pay packages.
snippet: Politicians and theologians argue over how best to curb a perceived culture of escalating pay packages.
lead_paragraph: LONDON  The governor of the Bank of England, Mervyn King, gave a speech last spring denouncing the hubris of bankers. That same day, the British bank Barclays, despite a £1.6 billion write-down in 2007, disclosed a bonus of £21 million, or about $38 million, to its president, Robert Diamond Jr., for that year.

headline.main: Culture of Outsize Pay for Bankers, Born on Wall Street, Has Europe Fuming

abstract: Office vacancy rates in San Francisco have hovered at half the national level, but rents are so high that companies are crossing the bay to find space.
snippet: Office vacancy rates in San Francisco have hovered at half the national level, but rents are so high that companies are crossing the bay to find space.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif.  The residential real estate downturn in the suburbs surrounding Oakland and San Francisco has been frightening. Prices, even in exclusive communities in Contra Costa, Sonoma and Solano Counties, are down 40 percent or more since 2006. In the last 12 months, median home prices in the nine-county San Francisco Bay region have tumbled 32 percent, according to real estate reports.

headline.main: Bay Area Holds Commercial Appeal Despite Stumbles of Housing Market

abstract: Businesses may take an immediate write-off of up to $250,000 for equipment purchased in 2008, double the amount allowed in 2007.
snippet: Businesses may take an immediate write-off of up to $250,000 for equipment purchased in 2008, double the amount allowed in 2007.
lead_paragraph: GIVEN the economic climate, small-business owners may be loath to make major purchases of new equipment or furnishings this year. But for those with money and an inclination to spend it, now is a good time to buy, as Congress enacted generous tax incentives for this year only. Businesses considering major expenditures may realize significant tax savings if they act promptly.

headline.main: Time Is Running Out for New Tax Breaks
headline.print_headline: Time Is Running Out for New Tax Breaks

abstract: Internet peering points or co-location buildings are the best place businesses to get online, at a relatively low cost.
snippet: Internet peering points or co-location buildings are the best place businesses to get online, at a relatively low cost.
lead_paragraph: THE premier addresses of the Internet age include 56 Marietta Street in Atlanta, 210 North Tucker Avenue in St. Louis and 111 Eighth Avenue in Manhattan. They go by a variety of names, like carrier hotels, Internet peering points and co-locations. And while they may not be located in the fanciest office buildings, and many of them are not in the best parts of town, they are the best places for businesses to get online, taking advantage of huge swaths of reliable bandwidth at a relatively low cost.

headline.main: Where Businesses Go for Internet Reliability
